Posee un negocio D. fabricación D. vestidos para ocasiones como bodas, quinceañeras, y otros festejos, venD. accesorios como son coronas para reina y otros. Ella solicita un préstamo para la compra D. mercadería ya que se aproxima las fiestas D. Independencia por lo cual necesita comprar telas D. alta costura y accesorios, esto contribuirá a mejorar el negocio y contar materiales para confección D. vestidos.
Las aspiraciones son mejorar el negocio para ahorrar una cuota destinada a su retiro, dedicarse ha viajar.
texts.en:
Marta is 57 years old, married, and lives in San Miguel with her husband and daughter. She manufactures clothing items. Her business is making dresses for special occasions, such as weddings, quinceañeras (formal parties for girls turning 15), and others formals. She also sells accessories, such as tiaras, etc. She is asking for this loan in order to buy supplies, as the Independence Day festivals approach. She needs to buy high quality fabrics and accessories. This will help her improve the business and allow her to have dress making supplies on hand. She wants to improve her business so that she can save more money toward her retirement.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Dressmaking supplies

loans.name: Ruth Elisa

texts.es:
Ruth tiene 30 años de edad, reside en el Municipio de Delicias de Concepción, departamento de Morazán, es casada tiene dos hijos de las edades de 11 y 4 años, ella se dedica a la elaboración de hamacas.
Hace cinco años Ruth y el esposo elabora hamacas, el negocio está ubicado en la casa de habitación y las comercializan con personas que visitan el lugar. Ella necesita un préstamo para la compra de hilos de seda de diferentes colores, esto contribuirá a generar trabajo y mejorar los ingresos de la familia.
Las aspiraciones de Ruth son mejorar la casa y apoyar a los hijos con los estudios, mejorar el sistema de vida de la familia.
texts.en:
Ruth is 30 years old and lives in the town of Delicias de Concepcion, in the department of Morazan. She is married and has two children, 11 and 4 years old. She weaves hammocks. Ruth and her husband have been weaving hammocks for five years. Their business is located in their home where they sell the hammocks to people who visiting town. She needs a loan to purchase silk threads of assorted colors. This will help generate work and increase the family's income. Ruth's aspirations are to improve her house, to sponsor her children's education and to improve her family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of silk threads of assorted colors

loans.name: Maria Santos

texts.es:
María tiene 35 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Arambala, Departamento de Morazán, es madre soltera, tiene cuatro hijos de las edades de 18,17,9 y 7 todos estudian actualmente, ella tiene una venta de comida y antojitos.
Hace 10 años se dedica a la elaboración de comida y antojitos (tostadas de plátano, yuca, papas frita) ella es una mujer trabajadora que todos sus esfuerzos son para apoyar a sus hijos. Ella solicita actualmente un préstamo para compra de una cocina industrial con plancha para hacer pupusas, esto contribuirá a generar trabajo a para que ella obtenga ingresos y mejore las condiciones de vida la familia.
Los sueños de María son apoyar a sus cuatro hijos para que terminen los estudios.
texts.en:
María is 35 years old and lives in the town of Arambala, Morazán Department. She is a single mother; she has four children aged 18, 17, 9 and 7. They are all in school. She has a business selling meals and snacks. Ten years ago she started making meals and snacks (tostadas with plantains, cassava, and potatoes). She is a very hard-working woman who puts all her effort into supporting her children. María is requesting a loan to purchase an industrial stove with a press for making pupusas [a Salvadoran stuffed tortilla]. This will help her generate work so she can have more income and improve her family's living conditions. María's dreams are to support her four children so they can finish their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Industrial stove with press for pupusas

loans.name: Xinia Guadalupe

texts.es:
Xinia tiene 36 años de edad reside en el municipio de Concepción Batres, departamento de Usulután, es acompañada y vive con el cónyuge y una hija de 17 años de edad quien le ayuda a trabajar, tiene un negocio de elaboración y venta de comida.
el negocio lo inicio hace 15 años gracias a la ayuda de una señora a quien ella ayudaba anteriormente, hoy tiene su negocio propio y trabaja en un horario de 6:00am- 2:00pm; actualmente ella no cuenta con el dinero para invertir en el negocio por lo cual está solicitando un préstamo, ella compraría una cocina industrial con plancha para elaborar tordillas de maíz, también invertir en materiales para elaboración de alimentos. Contribuirá a mantener el negocio, genera ingresos para solventar necesidades básicas de la familia.
Las aspiraciones de Xinia son tener un comedor amplio que le permita  generar un mejor sistema de vida a la familia.
texts.en:
Xinia is 36 years old and lives in the district of Concepción Batres, in the department of Usulután. She lives with her partner and 17 year old daughter, who helps in her business preparing and selling food. Xinia began her business 15 years ago, thanks to the help of a lady who she had helped earlier. Today, she has her own business and works from 6:00am to 2:00pm. At present, she does not have the money she needs to invest in her business and has therefore requested this loan. She will use the loan to pay for a professional kitchen, in which she will make corn tortillas. She will also use the money to buy cooking materials. The loan will enable her to continue her business and generate an income to meet the basic needs of her family. Xinia hopes one day to have a large dining room, which will contribute to a better quality of life for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Cameron Graham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for a professional kitchen, for making corn tortillas.

loans.name: Rogelio Jaime

texts.es:
Rogelio tiene 33 años de edad reside en el municipio de El Transito, departamento de Usulután, es casado vive con la esposa y dos hijos de las edades de 7 y 2 años, posee un taller de estructuras metálicas.
El negocio lo inicio hace 10 años, gracias a la ayuda de un amigo que tiene un taller quien le enseño el trabajo, no tiene horario definido y trabaja por contrato , el solicita  un préstamo para la compra de materiales como son hierro, chapas, pintura y  otros materiales necesario para realizar el trabajo. Esto contar con el material para hacer puertas metalicas y obtener ingresos que le permitan gastos en el hogar. 
Las aspiraciones son ampliar el taller y así apoyar a su joven familia para mejorar las condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Rogelio is 33 years old. He lives in the city of El Transito in the department of Usulután. He is married and lives with his wife and two children, ages 7 and 2. He has a workshop where he builds metal structures. He began this business twelve years ago, thanks to the help of a friend that had a workshop and taught him how to do this kind of work. He doesn’t have fixed work hours and works when we has customer requests. He is asking for a loan to buy materials such as iron, metal plate, paint and other materials he needs for his business. The material he needs will be used to make metal doors so that he has earnings to pay for housing costs. He aspires to expand his workshop and in this way support his young family and improve the conditions of their lives.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials such as iron, metal plate and paint.

loans.name: Herminda Del Carmen

texts.es:
Herminda tiene 40 de edad, reside en el municipio de San Rafael de Oriente, Departamento de San Miguel, es madre soltera y vive con su única hija, ella vende tortillas de maíz.
El negocio de venta de tortilla lo inicio hace 9 años, por la necesidad económica después que falleció el compañero de vida, trabaja todos los días de 8:00am- 4:00pm, ella esta solicitando un préstamo para compra de maíz, cal, gas, esto le permitirá con la continuidad del negocio y mejorar los ingresos.
Las aspiraciones son mantener el negocio para generar ingresos, cubrir los gastos económicos de la familia.
texts.en:
Herminda is forty years old and lives in the municipality of San Rafael de Oriente in the Department of San Miguel. She is a single mother and lives with her only daughter. She sells corn tortillas. She has been selling tortillas for the past nine years. She needed to do this to support herself after her life partner died. She works each day from 8:00am until 4:00pm. She is asking for this loan in order to buy corn, lime and cooking fuel. This will allow her to continue with her business and improve her earnings. In the future she hopes to maintain her business in order to have an income to use to cover the economic expenses of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn, lime and cooking fuel.

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Ana Iveth

texts.es:
Ana tiene 27 años de edad, reside en el Municipio de Sociedad Departamento de Morazán, esta acompaña vive con el esposo y dos hijos de las edades 2 y 5 años, ella se dedica a la venta de pupusas.
Tiene dos años de experiencia en el negocio, el cual está ubicado próximo a la iglesia y lo atiende de 5:00am- 7:00pm todos los días, los cliente en su mayoría son personas que visitan la iglesia y que circulan por la zona. ella solicita un préstamo para compra de maíz, quesillo, frijoles, chicharon, gas, este dinero ayudara al negocio para que Ana obtenga ingresos y mejorar las condiciones de vida de la familia.

Los sueños de Ana son comprar un terreno donde pueda vivir ella y sus hijos para que tengan una mejor vida.
texts.en:
Ana is 27 years old and lives in the municipality of Sociedad in the department of Morazán. She lives with her husband and two children ages 2 and 5. She sells pupusas (a corn dumpling filled with cheese, beans or meat) She has been doing this business for two years. It is located next to a church. She works from 5am until 7pm each day. The majority of her customers are people that visit the church or that visit this zone. She is asking for a loan in order to buy corn, cheese, beans, fried pig skin and cooking fuel. This money will help her business so that she can obtain earnings and improve the lives of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy corn, cheese, beans, fried pig skin and cooking fuel.

loans.name: Cristino

texts.es:
Cristino tiene 30años de edad, reside en el municipio de Cacaopera, Departamento de Morazán, está acompañando, vive con la esposa y su pequeño hijo de un  1 año de edad, el tiene una venta de frutas y  verduras.
Tiene tres los de experiencia en el negocio y su venta está ubicada en la calle, los clientes son personas que transitan el lugar, regularmente atiende el negocio de 6:00am- 5:00pm, el solicita un préstamo para la reparación  del vehículo donde transporta las verduras y frutas, también invertir en la compra de plátanos, papas, tomates, naranjas, manzanas, bananas que son productos que demanda sus clientes. Esto contribuirá a mejorar los ingresos de la familia y mantener el negocio.
Las aspiraciones de Cristino son tener un negocio prospero, comprar un carro en mejores condiciones para transportar las frutas y verduras, para darle a la familia mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Cristino is 30 years old and lives in the town of Cacaopera, Morazán Department. He lives with his wife and their little one-year-old son. Cristino has a business selling fruits and vegetables. He has three years of experience with this business, and his sales stall is located on the street. His customers are people who pass by the place. He runs the business regularly from 6:00 am until 5:00 pm. He is asking for a loan to repair the vehicle he uses for transporting the vegetables and fruits. He also wants to invest in purchasing plantains, potatoes, tomatoes, oranges, apples and bananas, which are products his customers demand. This will help to improve his family's income and maintain his business. Cristino's aspirations are to have a prosperous business, buy a better car to transport the fruits and vegetables, and give his family better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruits and vegetables, and repair a vehicle

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia R. is from the village of Sapang Ama, Sapang Dalaga. She is 53 years old, married, and has two adult children. To make a living, Lydia owns and operates a general store. Her main source of income comes from selling basic household items in the local community. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Lydia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid her previous loan of 14,950 PHP. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 14,950 PHP. She will use the money to purchase additional stock for the store. This loan is Lydia's ninth loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template to help Field Partners continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for the store

location.town: Sapang Ama Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidental

loans.name: Buenaventurada

texts.en:
Buenaventurada R. is from the village of Mitimos, Rizal. She is 59 years old, married, and has two adult children. To make a living, Buenaventurada grows corn and sells it in the local community. Buenaventurada has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Buenaventurada joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Buenaventurada has successfully repaid her previous loan of 10,000 PHP. Buenaventurada is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used for corn production. This loan is Buenaventurada's eighth loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template to help Field Partners continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for corn production

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn B. is from the village of Medallo, Sapang Dalaga. She is 35 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Roselyn grows assorted crops and sells them in the local community. Roselyn has been engaged in this business for over 12 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Roselyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation. Roselyn has successfully repaid her previous loan of 12,000 PHP. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Roselyn is requesting a new loan of 10,500 PHP which she will use to complete the construction of her house. This loan is Roselyn's  ninth loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template to help Field Partners continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house completion

loans.name: Jelyn

texts.en:
Jelyn M. is from the village of Minlasag, Sibutad. She is 34 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jelyn grows crops and sells them in the local community. Jelyn has been engaged in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2007, Jelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation. She has successfully repaid her previous loan of 7,000 PHP. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Jelyn is requesting a new loan of 10,500 PHP which she will use for house repair. This loan will be her fourth loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template to help Field Partners continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Rosaline

texts.en:
Rosaline C. is 33 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. She is from the village of Mitacas, Baliangao. To make a living, Rosaline grows rice and sells it in the local community. She has been operating her business for 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Rosaline joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosaline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 PHP from PMPC. Rosaline is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used for rice production. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Rosaline from PMPC. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena B. is from the village of New Dapitan, Rizal. She is 35 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lorena owns & operates a general store selling dry goods in the local community. Lorena has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lorena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Lorena is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used for capital for fruit vending. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lorena from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Additional capital for fruit vending

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en: Lilibeth M. is from the village of Sipaloc, Sibutad. She is 42 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Lilibeth owns and operates a general store, selling dry goods (products such as textiles, ready-to-wear clothing, and sundries) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Lilibeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to invest in hog and poultry raising. This loan will be her 6th from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To make a new investment in hog and poultry raising

loans.name: Renita

texts.en:
Renita M. is from the village of North Poblacion, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 39 years old. Renita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Renita owns & operates a furniture making business, making & selling bamboo beddings & other miscellaneous furniture to local businesses and community members. Renita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Renita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Renita is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Renita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional furniture.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha U. is from the village of Macabibo, Baliangao. She is 58 years old, married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Editha is engaged in weaving of "nipa", a native leaf, to sell. She has been operating her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 2000.00 a month. While her husband provides for their daily needs from his fishing business.

In 2005, Editha joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Editha has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Editha is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase housing materials. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Editha from PMPC. 
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase housing materials.

loans.name: Minda's Group

texts.en:
Minda D. is from the village of Caluya, Sapang Dalaga. She is 24 years old. Minda D. is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Minda is married and has 3 young children. To make a living, Minda owns & operates a fish vending business, primarily selling fresh, ocean-caught fish in the local community. Minda has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Minda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Minda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for the business. Minda is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used for house completion. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Minda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business for their daily needs. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Leonarda

texts.en:
Leonarda A. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Canbanwa, Argao, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  Fish vending and frozen foods businesses. Her husband, Mariano A. Jr., is 60 years old and helps in his wife's business activities. They have 4 children who are 21 to 25 years old. 

Leonarda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Leonarda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15000 increased her business turnover and helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 45000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 13th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 10000, which she intends to use to buy more frozen products and more fish to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future security of her family. Leonarda A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: Florenia

texts.en: Florenia U. is a 47-year-old widow who supports her family by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store, selling Ready-To-Wear clothes (RTW) and school supplies, and a herbal medicines dealership. She lives in Barangay Talisay, Santa Fe, Bantayan Island, Cebu. Florenia has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her sari-sari store , RTW and school supplies business and herbal medicine dealership, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP 10,000. Florenia is now borrowing PHP 29,500 so that her can increase her working capital. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Florenia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and insure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. By working hard in her food vending, firewood selling and general store businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 5,000 PHP. Analiza is now borrowing 11,000 PHP so that she can have additional working capital. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 9,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Analiza aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. The remaining amount will be used to finish their house. Vilma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially to meet their basic needs, to save for future use and for her children’s education, to make loan repayments, to pay for insurances, and to use for possible business expansions. texts.en: Soledad E. is a married woman who lives in Purok Puso, Barangay Buluang, Compostela, Cebu. Soledad earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and a scrap business. Her husband, Hilario E., who is 46 years old, buys and sells scrap and recyclable junk to earn his living and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 24 years old and 26 years old. Soledad joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,920, uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 10th loan, Soledad is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to add to the working capital of her sari-sari (general) store so that she can continue to save up for future business ventures and for house improvements. Soledad is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.name: Lolita Friolo's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Lolita Friolo, 48 years of age, married, is a resident of P2 Montol, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental.  Lolita is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lolita Friolo’s Group.

Lolita is blessed with 6 children of whom three are already married while the other three are now teenagers and presently working in different companies.  To earn their living, Lolita decided to engage in operating a sari-sari (variety) store. Also she is receiving support from her husband Segundino who is a farmer. For 3 years already, she was able to maintain her business  activities and at this time she is earning an average net income of not less than Php1,500 a month which is helpful to their family budget.

Upon hearing the good news of PAGLAUM MPC being one of the most outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao and awarded Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines during the search for COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006, she joined the cooperative this year, 2010. As a newly recognized member of the PDP-LP Program of PAGLAUM MPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting the amount of Php 4,000 as her 1st loan to be used as additional capital for her existing sari-sari store. The future income from this loan will be used to improve living conditions for her family, to meet their basic needs, for loan repayments to PMPC, savings and for possible business expansion.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen G., a married woman who lives in Brgy Zone III, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental, earns her living by operating a food vending business. Her husband, Armando G., 52 years old, works as a fish vendor and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have five children who range in age from 13 to 29 years old.

Helen joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow.

Helen's previous loan of PHP 7000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 2000, thereby uplifting the family's standard of living. For her seventh loan, she is requesting PHP 9000 as additional working capital for her food vending business so that she can continue to save up for her children's college education. Helen G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

This village bank loan has nineteen people who live in Chonloat Dai village, Takeo province. All members will use their portion of their loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Ry Y., who was born in 1957, is the village bank president who was selected by the other members. She and her husband, Mr. Kuck Sek, are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Her husband is also a stock broker in a private company. 

Though they try to work hard they can earn only a little money. So to improve her family's living, Mrs. Ry Y. is applying for a loan start a new business. She will purchase some piglets for breeding and pig food.  

She is the mother of five children, one of whom is a stock broker, another one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others are attending school.

Twenty-one people have selected Mrs. Seng U. as village bank president. They live in Chonloat Dai village, TaK. province, and they will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Seng U., who was born in 1969, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows rice to support her family. She is also a silk tier for weaving, while her husband, Mr. Seng Hort B., is a rock breaker and a construction worker. Now she wants to breed pigs, but she does not have enough money. To solve this problem, Mrs. Seng U. is seeking a loan to buy some piglets and pig feed to start a new business. She is the mother of four children: one is a driver while the others are enrolled in school.

texts.en:
Eva M. is a 31-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: fish vending and a pig fattening business. She lives in Prk. By working hard at her fish vending and pig fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She earns an average monthly income of PHP 7000. 

Eva is now borrowing PHP 29,500 which she intends to use as additional working capital in her in fish vending business, and she also plans to use part of it to put up a mini-grocery. Eva aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  'Dungganon' way.

loans.name: Alicia Pioquinto's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Alicia P., 58 years of age, married, is a resident of P1 Cogon, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental.  Alicia is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Alicia P.’s Group.

Alicia is blessed with 3 children of whom two are already married while the other one is still single and doing some business.  For their living, she decided to engage in operating a flower shop business.   Also she is receiving support from her husband Venancio who is her partner in operating their flower shop. For 6 years already in the flower shop business, she has been able to maintain the business  activity and now the couple is earning an average net income of not less than Php 6,000 a month which is helpful for their family budget. She joined the cooperative with no reservations this year, 2010. 

As a newly recognized member of the PDP-LP Program of PAGLAUM MPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out the rural poor, she is requesting the amount of Php 4,000 as her 1st loan to be used as additional capital for her existing flower shop business.  The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions for her family, to meet their basic needs, for loan repayments to PMPC, savings and for possible business expansion.

About PMPC:

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

texts.en: Liberata D. is a married woman who lives in Purok 3, Barangay Pungtod, Oslob, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: making and selling bibingka and torta (native filipino delicacies - see below) and hog fattening. Her husband, Jaime D., who is 59 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living. They have thirteen children who are from 4 to 32 years old. Bibingka is baked rice cake made from rice flour and coconut, while torta is anything dipped in egg-batter and deep fried. Liberata joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,600, uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 5th loan, Liberata is borrowing PHP 13,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital for her businesses so that she can continue to save for her plan to buy new equipment for her bibingka and torta business. Liberata is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. loans.name: Lessie

texts.en:
Lessie G. is a 54-year-old single woman who earns a living by operating two business ventures: hog raising and a sari-sari store. She lives in, Suba, Samboan, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her hog raising and sari-sari store businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of 4,000 PHP per month. 

Lessie is now borrowing PHP 19,500 so that she can have additional working capital for her hog raising business.  This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Lessie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Ramzan's Group

texts.en: Ramzan lives in Borewala — a small city in Pakistan. She is fifty-years of age, but still very active. She sews clothes for her neighborhood clients to make an income for her family. She is very good at her art and has been doing this work for the last fifteen years. Her experience leads her customers to give her orders on a regular basis. She uses her income to pay utilities expenses. Her husband makes marble floors; he sets the marble into the floor and then polishes it with a big polishing machine to make the marble smooth and bright. His son works with him. They used to rent the machine for their work since they couldn't afford to buy one. Ramzan's family is too poor to afford to educate her son so he started helping his father in his business at a very early age. Ramzan has applied for a loan from Asasah so that, together with the amount they have saved, her husband will be able to buy the polisher.

loans.use: Purchase a floor polishing machine

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran lives in a city in Pakistan called Borewala with her thirteen-year-old daughter and twelve-year-old son. Neither she nor her husband was able to get a good education because of family financial problems. Sugran is a very good mother, carries out her responsibilities as a housewife efficiently, and leads a five-member loan group. She helps support her family by buying bracelets in a wholesale market and selling them to different shops and neighborhood outlets. Her bracelets are well-known in her community, and sales are especially strong during Eid, a Muslim holiday that comes after Ramadan, because that's when these bracelets are most fashionable to wear.
  
Her husband makes a living as a farmer, growing wheat which he sells to his customers. He belongs to a family of farmers and loves this type of work. He is a very hard worker and is determined to improve his business. Sugran strongly supports him and wants to make sure he has the items he needs to increase the output of his fields. That is why she is applying for a new loan, her fourth, to help her husband buy seeds and fertilizer for his field. She is very much sure that her husband will be able to increase his income and the family will be able to repay the loan without any problem. 

Sugran has never missed a loan payment or failed to attend any of our organization's meetings.

Her husband, Mr. Van Megn, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he cultivates rice to sell to support his family. Her problem is that her husband’s field is far away from an irrigation system. To improve production, Mrs. Mao S. is seeking a loan to dig a well, and she will use the rest of the loan to purchase fertilizer. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a seamstress I. garment factory, while the youngest one is studying I. school.

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is very supportive of her family. She sews clothes by taking orders from different boutiques in her neighborhood and fulfills them on time to earn income for her family.

Nasreen is the mother of four children. She well knows the importance of education and wants to give quality education to her children. That’s why all of her children are getting an education in school.

Nasreen lives with her family in a city called Borewala in Pakistan where her husband runs a small restaurant. He serves tea and different kinds of Punjabi foods such as Nan chanay (famous Punjabi dish which made by chick peas and served with bread), kababs and lentils to his clients to make income. He has been running this business for over fifteen years and was the only breadwinner of his family before Nasreen's financial support. By presenting good quality food he has been able to improve his clientele base. He earns approximately 10,000 to 12,000 PKRs in profit.

Nasreen has applied for her third loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan, he will buy in bulk required items such as lentils, cooking oil, potatoes and spices to increase his sales. Nasreen is sure that, as a result of the increased income, she will be able to enjoy a better standard of living and will repay the loan with no problems.

Nasreen maintained a good credit behavior in the last two years and didn’t miss a single meeting.

loans.use: To purchase required items for her husband's restaurant

N. Ruth is 20 years old and lives in the town of Nasana in the Kampala East region of Uganda.  She is married and has 1 child who is currently in school.  Ruth has a business selling shoes, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Ruth is requesting a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more shoes. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. loans.name: Kennedy  Onyango

texts.en:
Kennedy A. is 33years old married man who lives in Rongo town in Western Kenya. He is married to Caroline Atieno, a business lady, and they have four children aged nine years, six years, four years, and one year,respectively.

Kennedy runs an open-air stall which sells household items like detergents, soaps, matches and much more. People prefer his products because they are cheaper compared to products on sale in big supermarkets.

Kennedy’s business is located along a busy highway which connects two towns: Rongo and Homabay. His main clients are road users along this route and also people from the nearby households.

Kennedy joined KADET and has qualified for a first loan of Kshs 20,000. He plans to use this loan to buy more household items to sell. He is sure of making more profits with this loan to boost his business. 

Kennedy’s dream is to one day construct a permanent premises, unlike his current open-air stall which is not conducive when it is raining.

loans.name: Joice

texts.en: Joice N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala east region of Uganda. She is single and has one child in school. Joice has had a business of selling phone airtime and phone charging for less than one year. To help expand her business, Joice is requesting a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more airtime to sell and chargers to use. Joice plans to use the loan in order to purchase inventory she was lacking, and generate profit in order to help her child. In the future, Joice hopes to develop her business further. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more phone airtime

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:

She has been engaged in this kind of business for five years and earns approximately $225 a month from this business activity. 

In the year 2009, Mercy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercy, as an active member of PMPC under the Regular Loan Program, has successfully repaid a loan of 20,000 PHP. She is now requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP as her 2nd loan, to be used for purchasing an additional motorcab unit and also as additional capital for their fish-selling business. 

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, as savings for future use and their children’s education, loan repayments, insurance and possible business expansions.

She hopes to go back to school for her studies and to go on to university.

loans.name: Truphena Awino

texts.en:
Truphena is a 43-year-old lady from Migori town. She is married to Phinehas O.. They have three children between the ages of 27 and 20 years.  They live in Uriri on the outskirts of Migori town in Western Kenya.

Truphena runs a cereal business where she sells all types of cereals, but mainly maize and beans due to their high demand. Although she is based in Uriri town, she sometimes supplies her cereals in Nairobi, the capital city, which is 500 kilometers away.

Truphena was introduced to Kadet by a friend who was an existing client, and since she had always wanted financing to boost her business, she didn’t hesitate. She joined and she is now taking her fourth loan after successfully completing the other loans. She plans to use the loan to buy more stock of cereals to sell and also to use in her molasses business. 

Truphena dreams of buying a pickup van for transporting her cereals to her customers.

loans.name: John Opiyo

texts.en:
John Opiyo is an industrious and enterprising man, aged sixty three. He is married to Rael, a housewife. They have two children: Daniel, 24, who is a welder and Veril, 22, a teacher. 

John has been in the tailoring and dressmaking business for the last twenty-eight years and has vast experience in this art. He can design any kind of clothing and he feels that the speed of his business' growth would have been higher had he gotten access to micro-finance earlier, at the start up of his business. 

He is taking his third loan from Kadet after successfully completing two previous loans without default. He plans to use the loan to buy more clothing materials. He anticipates making profits this month of August because parents will be buying school uniforms for their children in preparation for the next semester. 

He also plans to use part of the loan to buy agricultural products to sell, like fruits and vegetables which are in high demand. He wants to do this to generate more income and also as a part of diversifying his business.

Apart from operating his current business, he dreams of becoming a leading supplier of fruits and vegetables.

She has been operating a green grocer business for the last nine years in Kehancha, a town located in the western part of Kenya along the shores of Lake Victoria.

Kemuma buys her stock from the nearby main markets and sells it in small quantities to her clientele who are mainly women within the Kehancha Administrative Centre. She is taking her fourth loan from Kadet Limited and intends to use it to buy cereals to sell. At the moment, she will buy maize and beans because they are in high demand.

Her dream is to own a cereal store and move from her current makeshift stall to a permanent premise. She hopes to get Kiva lenders to enable her achieve this dream.

loans.name: Martina  Onjak

texts.en:
Martina Onjak, 41, is married to James O., a businessman in Kehancha, a border town in Western Kenya. They have five children aged between 18 and 12 years old; the first born is in college while the youngest is in fourth grade.

Martina runs a hotel in Kehancha, near the administrative offices. Her clientele consists mainly of people working in the administrative offices and market shoppers. She prepares local popular dishes such as fish and omena (small fish). She has operated the business for the last 13 years and plans to use her fourth loan from Kadet Limited to expand her business by buying more foodstuffs such as sugar, flour and fish. She also plans to expand her other business of textile making.

Her future plan is to invest in rental houses by constructing them in Kehancha, where there is demand. With this, she believes the family income will increase.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuff for the hotel business.

loans.name: Rose Adhiambo

texts.en:
Rose Adhiambo N. is 33 years old and married with two children. She lives with her family in Nyamasaria Estate, a low income area in Kisumu City, and her spouse runs a motorcycle transport business. 

To supplement her husband’s income, Rose runs a fish selling business in the estate. Her main customers are women within Nyamasaria Estate. Fish is a popular dish in the area, which attributes to her generating a monthly income of 16,000 KES ($200). She joined Kadet Ltd. to access financial services and she hopes to use her first loan to buy more fish for sale. Apart from this, she plans to maintain a good repayment record so that she can qualify for more loans from Kadet Ltd.

Rose is a visionary who feels the sky is the limit. She plans to expand her market base and become a fish supplier to nearby towns. This she believes will increase her income and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more fish for sale.

loans.name: Monica Atieno

texts.en:
Monica is a 45-year-old widow living in Sondu, an upcoming town next to Kisumu City along Lake Victoria. Monica’s husband died and she was left with the responsibility of taking care of four children; two are in high school while the other two are in primary school. 

Monica sells secondhand clothes (locally known as mitumba) at her clothes stall within Sondu. She has been in this business for the last eight years and is experiencing growth due to the high demand for this clothing in the area. This she confirms through her monthly income of KES 10,000 ($125). This is the fourth loan that Monica is getting from Kadet Ltd and she intends to buy more stock for sale and from the profits she anticipates to generate, Monica plans to open a wholesale shop.

Monica is determined to support her children in school and to see that they have a better standard of living. This determination makes her work hard and pay her loans successfully so that she can be considered for subsequent loans.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing for sale

loans.name: Rafig

texts.ru:
Rafig Mamedovu 64 qoda. On jenat i imeyet dvux detey (sinovey) kotorim 25 i 27 let. Odin iz eqo sinovey jenat i toje imeyet dvux detey kotorim 2 i 5 let . A eqo mladshiy sin ne jenat  on pomoqayet svoyemu otcu v eqo rabote,toje sobirayetsya jenitsya. Rafig Mamedov i eqo semya jivut v qorode Baku.

Biznesom Rafiga yavlyayetysa maqazin "1001 meloch" v Azebaydjane ,potomu chto on mojet prodovat vse chto mojet priqoditsya v povsednevnoy jizni ot zontika do iqolki( from umbrellas and needles to screwdrivers). Rafig uje 7 let rabotayet v etom biznese. On ochen lyubit svoyu rabotu. Ranshe on bil voditelem taksi no potom on reshil otkrit maqazin. Teper on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi uvelichit pomesheniye v naqazine dlya toqo chtobi pomestit tam bolshe novix tovarov.
texts.en:
Rafig Mamedov is 64 years old. He is married and has two sons, 25 and 27 years of age. One of his sons is already married and has his own children, a 2-year old and a 5-year old. They younger son is not yet married but planning to; he helps his father with the business. Rafig Mamedov and his family live in the city of Baku. Rafig’s business is a household goods store of the type known as “1001 things” in Azerbaijan. He sells all kinds of items needed in everyday life, from umbrellas and needles to screwdrivers. He has been in this business for 7 years. He likes his work. In the past he used to be a taxi driver but later he decided to open his own store. At present Rafiq needs 2000 AZN in order to expand his space and accommodate more new goods.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing store space

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:

She is blessed with 2 children who are now school-aged. She is presently engaged in operating a sari-sari (variety) store. She also receives support from her husband from his income as a driver. Alma has been involved in this business for 4 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Alma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma, as an active member of PMPC under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program, has successfully repaid a loan of 14,900 PHP. She is now requesting a loan of 30,000 PHP (her 5th loan) to be used as additional capital for her sari-sari business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions, especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, the children’s education, loan repayments, insurance and possible business expansions.

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

With the 20,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase two sacks of mango fruits, pineapple, oranges and avocados. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her goal is to be self-reliant and to open another soft drink shop in future. Amina decided to go to Yehu for financial assistance. She rents a house with electricity and piped water. texts.en:
Mila C. is from the village of Bandera. She is 56 years old. Mila is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is C. Group.

Mila is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Mila works in a family member's business planting & harvesting rice to sell. Mila has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mila is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mila from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman with two children; one attends school while the other one is still too young for school. She has been operating her tailoring business for the last ten years. She sells in a shop, her major customers being companies, schools, and the neighboring community. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase a bundle of materials and other tailoring equipment. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. Mwanajuma hopes to prosper in life and be self-reliant. She decided to work with Yehu so as to get financial support. She owns a house with electricity, but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

Teodora is just starting this business.

texts.en:

Presently, S. has another financial earner in her husband who works on the farm planting various crops. 

S. is taking out this loan as capital towards purchasing fertilizer, insecticide, and seed to begin growing crops when the farming season comes. S. and her husband are pictured above at their house.

loans.name: Nushaba

texts.ru:
Nushaba B. 33 qoda. Ona zamujem i imeyet dvux detey (sin 5 let i devochka 9 let). Dochka Nushaba B. uchitsya v shkole  i zanimayetsya tancami. Ona ochen lubit uchitsya i starayetsya uchit svoyeqo malenkoqo brata raznim stixam. Tak je ona lubit pomoqat svoyey mame. Yeyo mladshiy sin uchitsya v detskom sadike i on ochen lyubit iqrat so svoyey sestroy. Nushaba yavlyayetsya pereselencem iz Agdama, okupirovannaya teritoriya Azerbaydjana , i teper ona i yeyo semya jivut v qorode Baku. 

Nushaba otkrila svoy maqazin 3 qoda nazad. Ona ochen lyubit svoy biznes po yeyo slovam on ochen udobniy dlya neyo ved ona mojet videlit vremya svoyey semye koqda yey nujno. Etomu biznesu ona nauchilas u svoyeqo brata kotoriy ochen pomoq yey. Seychas Nushaba nujdayetya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkti dlya pereprodaji i razvitiya biznesa.
texts.en:
Nushaba B. is 33 years old. She is married and has two children (a 5-year old son and a 9-year old daughter). Her daughter is in school and also goes to a dance studio. She enjoys her studies and tries to teach various poems to her little brother. She also likes helping her mother. Nushaba’s son goes to kindergarten and likes playing with his sister. Nushaba is a refugee from Agdam, the occupied territory of Azerbaijan, and now she and her family live in the city of Baku. Nushaba opened her store three years ago. She likes being in this business and says that it gives her flexibility to attend to family needs. She has learned this business from her brother, who has been helping her a lot. At present Nushaba needs 2000 AZN in order to purchase groceries for resale, which will help her grow her business.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restocking groceries

loans.name: Thiem

texts.en:
Mrs. N. is a 41-year-old married woman. She is a villager who lives in a medium-sized home with family members in Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She and her husband use this land to grow different kinds of crops, including potatoes, morning glories and rice.
Mrs. N. grows crops every year and has had great success. However, she doesn’t have capital to use on her field during this coming rainy season. Therefore, she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and seeds to begin growing. With any remaining money from the loan, Mrs. N. will buy three piglets to raise for extra income.
Note: Mrs. N.'s husband is shown in the photo above.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

She decided to work with Yehu so as to get a loan and expand her business. Grace rents a house with neither electricity nor piped water. She cites school fees as her greatest monthly expense.

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Mrs. Em P. is a 34-year-old rice grower from the Kompong Cham Province. (Her husband also appears in the photo.) She runs her business on her own farmland, where she grows different kinds of crops like cabbages, rice, potatoes and morning glories. She sells the crops to a buyer when they have matured. Her husband helps her with the farm work. 

Em P. has four school-aged children. All four of them are students but work on the farm when they are free from school. With the rainy season approaching and the heavy rains falling, it is a good time for planting. However, Em P. does not have enough farm supplies to use on her field. Em P. is therefore asking for capital to use toward purchasing fertilizer and seeds for growing.

loans.use: To use toward purchasing fertilizer and seeds for growing

loans.name: Mrs. Koem Chun Maen Village Bank Group

texts.en:
PO. village, Takeo province, has 19 people who make up a village bank. Mrs. Koem ChU. M. is the village bank president, selected by the other members, who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Koem ChU. M. and her husband are farmers who own a 2 hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to support their family. She is also a vegetable seller, while her husband is an ice cream seller door-to-door. She was born in 1983 and is the mother of two children, one of whom is attending school, while the youngest one is 3 years old. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil. To improve her production of rice, Mrs. Koem ChU. M. is asking for a loan to buy rice seed. She will use the rest of the loan to buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To buy rice seed
