loans.name: Deun

texts.en: Mrs. Deun L. has been in the farming business for years. She plants rice crops on her own land, from which she earns a living. Her husband assists her with the farm work. Deun L. has been married for years and has two children, both attending school. Deun L. hopes to improve her daily income. To help meet her goals, Deun L. has applied for a loan to use as capital in order to buy mature rice in bulk from other farmers to store for a while before selling it for a profit.

loans.use: To buy mature rice in bulk from other farmers to store for a while before selling

loans.name: Leonora's Group

texts.en:
Leonora E. is from the village of Labakid. She is 47 years old. Leonora is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. 

Leonora is married. To make a living, Leonora operates a food vending business. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Leonora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Leonora from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for production

loans.name: Esterlita's Group

texts.en:
Esterlita F. is from the village of Dapaon. She is 50 years old. Esterlita is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are each responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. 

Esterlita is married. To make a living, Esterlita owns & operates a canteen business venture. Esterlita has been engaged in her business for over 19 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Esterlita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esterlita has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Esterlita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Esterlita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy products to sell

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora D. is from the village of Dalacon. She is 50 years old. Leonora is widowed and has 8 children. To make a living, Leonora owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Leonora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Leonora from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Gideon

texts.en: Gideon is a hardworking 33-year-old man. For six years, he has been running Fair Deal Auto Tech shop where he sells vehicle spare parts. He employs two people because he also runs a retail shop and does farming. He was previously a mechanic, which is how he got into the business of selling spare parts. He joined Arise & Shine group with Faulu Kenya, whose members are accountable for any member who takes a loan. With the group, he has previously received two loans. He has requested 50,000 KES to purchase shock absorbers, bearings, and rims. He hopes to expand his shop and move to a larger location. Gideon is the father of Shirleen, a one-year-old girl.

loans.use: To buy shock absorbers, bearings, and rims

loans.name: Mr. Sokhorn Li Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has 16 people who have been selected by Mr. Sokhorn L., the village bank president, who is 34 years old. They are located in Pou village in Takeo province. Each member will use his or her portion of the loan in a variety of ways in order to improve their quality of life. Mr. Sokhorn L. is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land where he cultivates rice to sell to support his family.  Meanwhile, his wife, Mrs. Sary T., is a housewife. He tries to work hard, and he wants to expand his business so as to improve his family's living conditions. Mr. Sokhorn L. is asking for a loan to buy rice seed and to hire a plow machine to plow his field. He is a father of six children, three of whO. are studying in school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and hire a plow

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a single man.  He runs a retail shop where he employs one person.  He is also a web designer and was able to buy a laptop through a loan from Faulu Kenya.  He is requesting another loan of 50,000 KES to add stock in his retail shop and set up a grocery store.  He hopes to open a supermarket in the future.  He is also hoping to set up a cyber café 10 years from now so as to employ more people. He describes himself as outgoing, hardworking, business-oriented, and focused.

loans.use: To add stock in his shop and set up a grocery store

loans.name: Seab

texts.en: Mrs. Seab S. is a 38-year-old married woman and a villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Cham province. She owns a piece of farmland that she uses to grow different kinds of crops. She is married with two school-aged children and her husband works on the farm with her. The coming rainfall is good for growing; however, Seab S. does not have capital to use on her farm. Seab S. is looking for a loan to use toward purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and seeds for planting. Mrs. Seab S. was not available when the photo was taken so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and seeds

loans.name: Hai

texts.en: Mrs. Hai N. was born in 1951 and she is living in Angk Sangkae village, Takeo province. She is a pig breeder and she also sells mosquito nets and blankets. Her husband, Mr. Chorn Prum, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. Now her pig breeding is going so well that she wants to expand her business. So to improve this goal, Mrs. Hai N. is seeking for a loan to buy pig food, a pump machine, and the rest of the loan she will buy a new motorbike for transportation. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a clerk while the other is studying in the local public school. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy pig food and a pump machine.

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is a member of Pamoja 45 group at Faulu Kenya. He operates Realtime Salon and Barber shop. Being in the business for fifteen years, he employs one person. He also runs a cereal shop and was previously employed as a driver. David, a father of two, works hard to provide for his family. He hopes to educate his children at the university level and also to build his own house in the future. As a member of a group in Faulu Kenya, he can easily access a loan. He has previously received one loan. He has requested another loan of 50,000 KES to purchase a shaving machine, sterilizer, seats, and mirrors. He describes himself as a hardworking and visionary man.

loans.use: To purchase a shaving machine, sterilizer, seats and mirrors

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. Sok V. has spent her entire life cultivating crops on her own land. She specializes in growing rice, a skill she learned from her grandparents when she was young. She harvests the crops for the purposes of eating and selling. Sok V. is now married and has two school-aged children. Her husband frequently works in the farm fields alongside her. Growing rice is an annual operation with which she has had great success for several years. The farming season is approaching, and Sok V. wants to plant the next rice crop. She does not have capital to use for her farm, so she decided to request a loan from Kiva to purchase fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and seeds.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other items for rice crop

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 42 years old and married with three children.  She has been operating a retail shop where she sells tea leaves, sugar, bread, cereals and sweets.  She has been in the business for 10 years.  She also does farming to earn extra income.  She has requested 40,000 KES to buy sugar, soda, bread and salt.  She hopes to improve her business for better income.  She wants to be in a position to educate her children to a higher education level in the future.  She wants to have a wholesale shop in 10 years.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soda, bread and salt

loans.name: Thlong

texts.en: Mrs. Thlong Y. is a professional rice farmer who has spent her entire life cultivating crops on her own land, a skill she learned from her grandparent. She also harvests the crops for the dual propose of eating and selling. Thlong Y. is now married and has five children. Three of the children are already married and live independently. The other two are single. Her husband frequently works in the fields along side her. Growing rice is an annual operation with which she has had great success for several years. Thlong Y. hopes to plant the next rice crop since the farming season is coming, but she doesn’t have capital to use on her farm. So, she decided to borrow a loan from Kiva to buy farm supplies in order to grow rice.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies in order to grow rice

loans.name: Son

texts.en: Shown in the photo are Son V. and her husband who have spent their life cultivating crops. This is a skill they learned from their grandparents. This couple was married years ago and they have three children. Two of the children are married and one is single. Growing crops is an annual action with which they have had great success for several years. The family is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. The coming rainfall is good for growing; however, the family doesn’t have capital to use on their farm. So Son V. discussed this with her husband and decided to seek a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizers and seeds for planting.

loans.use: To use towards purchasing fertilizers and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita B. is from the village of Katipa. She is 55 years old. Carmelita is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Carmelita owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Carmelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Carmelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita D. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 53 years old. Nenita is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Nenita owns & operates a business selling personal home products to tourists and local community members. Nenita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Nenita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Nenita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth C. is from the village of Rizal, Lopez Jaena. She is 57 years old. Elizabeth is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a business selling home products. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling personal home products to tourists and local community members. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Elizabeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Elizabeth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta B. lives in the village of Upper Puntod, Lopez Jaena. She is 51 years old, married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, she runs a shop where she sells dried goods. Vicenta has been in this business for more than two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. Vicenta has successfully repaid four previous loans from PMPC which she used to buy more items to sell and acquire more working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell and acquire more working capital

loans.name: Sope Serigne Ibra Bousso Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOPE SERIGNE IBRA BOUSSO est créé depuis 6 mois. Il est composé de 15 femmes toutes du même village. Elles ont formé leur groupe par voisinage et par affinité. Le groupe de solidarité fait partie du Banc Villageois de BOFFEL
Madame SENEB. S., debout à droite sur la photo est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 50 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 07 enfants en charge. 
Elle fait de l’embouche ovine et de la transformation et vente d’huile d’arachide. Elle fait cette activité depuis bientôt 5 ans. 
Son second prêt avec CAURIE-MICRO FINANCE lui permettra d’acheter 2 moutons qu’elle va emboucher pendant au moins 4 mois avant de les revendre dans les marchés hebdomadaires. Elle va acheter également des arachides pour faire de la transformation en huile d’arachide. 
Son objectif est de participer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille et de renforcer le bien-être de ses enfants.
texts.en:
The Sope Serigne Ibra Bousso solidarity group was created six months ago. It is made up of 15 women, who all come from the same village and are either neighbors or good friends. The solidarity group is part of the Banc Villageois in Boffel. Mrs. SeneB. S., who is standing on the right in the photo, is in charge of the solidarity group. She is 50 years old, married and mother to seven children, who are in her care. She has a sheep fattening activity and also makes and sells peanut oil. She has been doing this for almost five years. Her second loan from Caurie-Microfinance will allow her to buy two sheep which she will fatten up for at least four months before reselling them at the weekly markets. She is also going to buy peanuts in order to make peanut oil. Her aim is to contribute to the improvement in her family's living conditions and to strengthen her children's welfare.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase two sheep and peanuts

loans.name: Kem

texts.en: Mrs. Kem S. is a 42-year-old married woman who lives with her family in Kompong Cham Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents which she and her husband use today to grow different crops, including potatoes and rice. Planting her crops is an annual event with which she has had great success. Kem S. is applying for this loan to buy fertilizer and seeds to begin planting a new crop of potatoes and rice

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds to begin planting her next crop.

loans.name: Artemia

texts.en:
Artemia S. lives in the village of Poblacion Manukan. She is 65 years old, married and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Artemia owns and operates a food stall. She has been in this business for more than 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Artemia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC, and has applied for a new one, for 5,000 PHP, to buy additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa M. lives in the village of Biasong. She is 32 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Elsa fishes and sells her catch to people in her local community. She has been in this business for more than four years and earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2004, Elsa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid nine previous loans from PMPC and is now applying for a new one, for 30,000 PHP, to invest in her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to continue improving and expanding her business. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Mrs. Vong Ngen Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has fifteen people. All of the group's members have selected Mrs. Vong N. as village bank president. She is 30 years old. The group members are located I. Trapeang Dang Tuek village, Takeo province. All of the members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes I. order to improve their businesses I. the current year. Mrs. Vong N. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family while her husband, Mr.  Chea SE., is a firewood seller. Her problE. is that her field has infertile soil. So to improve rice production, Mrs. Vong N. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan she will hire farming laborers to help cultivate the rice. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are attending a local school, while the youngest one is two years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica M. lives in the village of Mansabay Bajo. She is 31 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store where she sells different items to people who live in her community. She has been engaged in this business for more than four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2008, Jessica joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid four previous loans from PMPC and is applying for a new loan, for 10,000 PHP, to buy additional items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to continue improving and expanding her business. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Peach

texts.en: Mrs. S. is a 20-year-old married woman and a villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Cham Province. She is blessed with a lovely daughter who is already enrolled in school. To earn a living, she owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandmother. She and her husband use this land to grow different kinds of crops including potatoes and rice. Growing crops is an annual activity with which she has had great success. S. doesn’t have enough capital for her farm during this coming rainy season. She is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, insecticide, a pump, and seeds.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide, a pump and seeds

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The borrower is 29 years old and married with two children. He graduated from intermediate school. The borrower will use this loan to purchase an electrical kneading machine and flour. The borrower has a good reputation in the market and is a skilled baker, making different kinds of bread. He has been working in this area for four years and has many clients. The borrower has an ambition to develop his business in the future in order to gain a higher income for his family.

loans.use: To purchase electrical kneading machine and flour

loans.name: Leang

texts.en:
Shown in the photo are Mrs. S. and her husband, who have spent their life cultivating crops. This is a skill they learned from their grandparents, who died years ago. They have two school-aged children. 

Growing crops is an annual business with which they have had great success over the years. The family is able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both the rainy and dry seasons. 

The coming rainfall is good for growing: however, the family doesn’t have enough capital to ensure successful crop growth. Mrs. S. discussed this with her husband and decided to seek assistance through this loan.

loans.use: To ensure successful crop growth

loans.name: Mrs. Sokheng Vaen Village Bank Group

texts.en: Seventeen people make up a village bank loan, live in Chrouy village, Takeo province. All of the members of this group will use a portion of their loan in various ways to improve their businesses. Mrs. Sokheng V. is a village bank president who was born in 1969, selected by the other members. She is a fish and rice middleman who is able to earn a large profit to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve her current business, Mrs. Sokheng V. is requesting for a loan to buy more fish and rice to resell. Her husband, Mr. Tet Mak, is a crippler and she has five children, two of whom are laborers, while three of whom are attending in local school and they are helping her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish and rice to resell.

loans.name: Sope Serigne Touba Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOPE SERIGNE TOUB. est créé depuis 6 mois. Il est composé de 24 femmes issues du même village. Ce sont des femmes qui ont évolué depuis leur jeune âge. C’est ainsi qu’elles ont formé leur groupe par voisinage et par affinité. Le groupe de solidarité fait partie du Banc Villageois de BOFFEL

Madame FAMA S. debout à droite sur la photo est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 48 ans. Elle est mère de 4 enfants en charge, elle a aussi la charge de sa petite fille. 

Elle fait de l’embouche ovine. Elle pratique cette activité depuis une décennie. 

Son nouveau prêt lui permettra d’acheter 3 mouton et de l’aliment de bétail. Elle va les engraisser pendant 5 mois avant de les vendre dans les marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité.

Son objectif est de subvenir à ses besoins personnels, de participer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille et de constituer une bonne épargne.
texts.en:
The Sope Serigne TouB. solidarity group was established six months ago. It is made up of 24 women who come from the same village. These women have grown close from an early age and formed the group as friends or neighbors. The solidarity group is part of the Banc Villageois in Boffel. Mrs. Fama S., who is standing at the right of the photo is in charge of the group. She is 48 years old and is mother to four children in her care; she also takes care of her granddaughter. She has a sheep fattening activity and has been carrying out this business for around ten years. Her new loan will allow her to buy three sheep and food for the livestock. She will fatten up the sheep for five months before selling them in the weekly markets in her town. Her goal is to provide for her personal needs, to contribute to an improvement in her family's living conditions and to build up a healthy level of savings.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase three sheep

loans.name: Sope Elhadj Malick Sy Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOPE ELHADJ MALICK SY est créé le 30 décembre 2009. Il est composé de 21 femmes. Elles sont toutes issues du même village. Elles ont formé leur groupe par voisinage et par affinité. Le groupe de solidarité fait partie du Banc Villageois de BOFFEL

Madame DIOGO D. debout à l’extrême droit sur photo est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 60 ans. Elle est mère de 2 garçons et 2 filles. Elle a également la charge de ses 2 petits fils. 

Son activité antérieure est le petit commerce. Avec son nouveau crédit elle va faire de l’embouche ovine

Avec son prêt elle va acheter 2 moutons et de l’aliment de bétail pour les emboucher pendant 5 mois avant de les revendre dans les marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité. 

Elle soutien son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille. Par exemple la nourriture et la santé.
texts.en:
The Sope Elhadj Malick Sy solidarity group was created on 30th December 2009. It is made up of 21 women who all come from the same village and are either neighbors or friends. The solidarity group is part of the Banc Villageois in Boffel. Mrs. Diogo D., who is standing on the extreme right of the photo is in charge of the solidarity group. She is 60 years old and mother to two boys and two girls. She is also responsible for her two grandsons. Her previous activity was the running of a small business. With her new loan she is going to fatten up sheep. She will buy two sheep and food for the livestock, in order to fatten them during five months and then sell them at the weekly markets in her town. She helps her husband to take care of the family, for example covering food and health costs.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase two sheep

loans.name: Wakilare Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité WAKILARE est créé depuis 11 ans. Il regroupe 7 femmes qui sont toutes du même quartier. Le groupe de solidarité fait partie du Banc Villageois de GADAPARA si tué dans la ville de Kolda. 

Madame Fatoumata S. à l’extrême droite de la photo est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 46 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants en charge.

Elle vend à domicile des produits alimentaires, tels du riz, de l’huile végétale, et des condiments de cuisine. 

Son prêt lui permettra d’acheter sa marchandise en quantité plus importante pour augmenter sa marge bénéficiaire. 

Son objectif est d’assurer la scolarité de ses enfants et de participer au payement de la nourriture. Elle soutien également son mari dans les différentes charge de la famille.
texts.en:
The Wakilare solidarity group was created eleven years ago. It groups together seven women who are all from the same neighborhood. The solidarity group is part of the Banc Villageois in Gadapara, which lies in the town of Kolda. Mrs. Fatoumata S., on the extreme right of the photo, is in charge of the solidarity group. She is 46 years old, married and mother to six children, who are all in her care. She sells food products from home, such as rice, vegetable oil and condiments. Her loan will allow her to buy a more significant quantity of goods in order to increase her profit margin. Her goal is to to provide for her children's schooling and to contribute to food costs. She also helps her husband with the various other household expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, vegetable oil and condiments

loans.name: Tacku Liggey Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité TACKU LIGGEY est créé  depuis la mise en place du Banc Villageois (GADAPARA) il y a de cela 11 ans. Le groupe est composé de 09 femmes qui sont toutes issues du même quartier. 

Madame AWA D. debout à l’extrême droite de la photo est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 30 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 04enfants.

Son activité consiste la vente de rafraichissement. Elle fabrique des jus naturels avec des produits du pays : pain de singe, feuilles d’oseille, gingembres etc. 

Son prêt lui permettra de s’approvisionner en quantité suffisante en produits de base pour ses jus afin d’augmenter sa production de jus.

Elle participe financièrement à la prise en charge de sa famille. A partir de ses bénéfices renforce son niveau d’épargne.
texts.en:
The TACKU LIGGEY solidarity group was created after the GADAPARA Banc Villageois was established 11 years ago. The group is composed of 9 women who all come from the same neighborhood. Mrs. AWA D., standing at the extreme right in the photo, is the leader of the solidarity group. She is 30 years old, married and the mother of four children. Her business consists of selling cold drinks. She makes natural juices with home-grown products: monkey bread, sorrel leaves, ginger, etc. Her loan will enable her to stock up with raw materials for her juices in sufficient quantity to increase her juice production. She contributes financially to the support of her family and will expand her savings from her earnings.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop her commercial business

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
M. Olivia is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala East region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Olivia has a business of selling second-hand clothing, which she has had for one year.         

Olivia is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more clothes.  Olivia plans to use the loan in order to expand her business by buying more clothes and generate a profit in order to change her lifestyle.  In the future, Olivia hopes to get married and have a good life.

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Gorgorlou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité GORGORLOU est créé au 7è cycle du Banc Villageois de GADAPARA en 2006. Il est composé de 07 femmes issues du même quartier. Elles ont formé leur groupe par solidarité et voisinage.

Madame Aminata D. debout à droite sur la photo est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 46 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants. 

Elle vend des jus de fruits naturels qu’elle fabrique de ses propres mains. La vente se fait à domicile et au marché central de son quartier.

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va acheter des fruits et condiments pour la fabrique de ses jus

Elle a comme objectif de payer la scolarité de ses enfants, de participer à la nourriture de la famille tout en renforçant son niveau d’épargne.
texts.en:
Solidarity group GORGORLOU was created in 2006, during the seventh cycle of the "Banc Villageois de GADAPARA". It is composed of seven women from the same neighborhood. They created their group out of solidarity and because they are neighbors. Mrs. Aminata D., standing on the right in the picture, is the head of the group. She's 46 years old, married, and the mother of four children. She sells natural fruit juices that she makes herself. She sells at her home, as well as at the central market in her neighborhood. She will use her new loan to buy fruits and ingredients needed to make her juices. Her goal is to pay her children's school expenses and help feed her family, while at the same time bolstering her savings.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits and ingredients to make fruit juices

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
N. Margret is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala East region of Uganda. She is married and has no children. Margret has a business selling charcoal: an endeavor she has pursued for three years.         

To help expand her business, Margret is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal. Margret plans to use the loan to expand her business and generate a better profit in order to help her family. 

In the future, Margret hopes to own a house and build a bigger business.

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal

loans.name: Tessito Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité TESSITO est né au 5è cycle du Banc Villageois de GADAPARA en 2007. Il est composé de 09 femmes toute issues du même quartier. Elles se sont organisées par voisinage et par affinité.

Madame NGALA SONA S., debout à droite de la photo, est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 56 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 7 enfants. 

Elle fait la vente de jus de fruits naturels. Des jus qu’elle fabrique de ses propres mains et qu’elle vend à domicile et au marché central du quartier.

Son prêt lui permettra de d’acheter des provisions pour la préparation de ses jus de fruits.

Elle cherche à travers les bénéfices qu’elle réalise à améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Par le payement de la scolarité de ses enfants et la nourriture de la famille.
texts.en:
Solidarity group TESSITO was created in 2007, during the fifth cycle of the "Banc Villageois de GADAPARA". It is composed of nine women, all from the same neighborhood. They got together out of affinity and because they are neighbors. Mrs. NGALA SONA S., standing on the right in the picture, is the head of the group. She's 56 years old, married, and the mother of seven children. She sells natural fruit juices, that she makes herself. She sells them at her home and at the central market in her neighborhood. This loan will enable her to buy the ingredients she needs to prepare her fruit juices. With her profits, she wants to improve the standard of living of her family, by paying for food and for her children's school expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits and ingredients to prepare fruit juices

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
N. Madina is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala east region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children.  One of her children is currently in school.  Madina has a business of selling soft drinks, which she has had for 3 years.         

To help expand her business, Madina is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more soft drinks like soda.  Madina plans to use the loan in order to expand her business, and generate profit in order to help her family.  In the future, Madina hopes to own a house.



Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Bokk Jubo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité BOKK JUBO est créé au jour de l’inauguration du Banc Villageois GADAPARA qui l’abrite. Il est composé de 08 femmes du même quartier. Elle son formé leur groupe par voisinage et par affinité. 

Madame AÏSSATOU SAME D. debout à droite de la photo, est responsable du groupe. Elle est une femme mariée de 47 ans. 

Elle est vendeuse des boubous en thioup. Elle s’approvisionne à la capitale à Dakar. Elle va sa marchandise au comptant et à crédit dans son quartier et environs. 

Elle va acheter en quantité suffisante des boubous en thioup afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et réaliser beaucoup plus de bénéfices 

Son objectif est d’aider son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille par exemple la nourriture et le payement de la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
The BOKK JUBO solidarity group was created when the GADAPARA Banc Villageois was established. It is supported by the Banc Villageois. It is composed of 8 women from the same neighborhood. They formed their group by neighborhood and kinship. Mrs. AÏSSATOU SAME D., standing at the right in the photo, is the leader of the group. She is a 47 year-old marrried woman. She sells boubous made from thioup (a hand-dyed fabric). She gets her supplies at the capital in Dakar. She sells her merchandise for cash and credit in her neighborhood and the surrounding area. She is going to buy thioup boubous in sufficient quantity so as to better satisfy her clientele and to make a much larger profit. Her goal is to help her husband support the family, for example to pay for the food and the schooling of her children.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Thioup fabric

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 44-year-old married man living in Lebanon with his wife and two children. Ali has owned a grocery shop since 2008 with 4 years of experience.  Ali sells fruits and vegetables, and he exudes the qualities of a responsible and friendly person. A constant flow of tourists visit his shop and the environment is very animated in the mornings when house wives meet in his shop to get their daily food needs. Ali is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua in order to add more shelves and stands to show the wide variety of goods he has, in addition to a front display refrigerator to show and keep the fruits fresh as long as he can. He would like to develop his work in the future through purchasing sodas, rice, sugar and other products.

loans.use: To add more shelves and stands.

loans.name: Kossiwa Nicole

texts.fr: A. est mariée et mère de 2 enfants, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commere de pagnes, elle fait ce commerce depuis Huit ans déjà. elle a déjà sollicité et obtenu de WAGES du crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé, elle sollicite ce troisième pour s'approvisionner et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, avec ce crédit elle pourra acheter 3 pièce de GTP, 6 pièces de WAX,  3 pièces de tissus à dentelle et divers.
texts.en:
Mrs. A. is married and the mother of two children. To generate income, she buys and sells "pagnes" (printed fabric), an activity she has been involved in for eight years already. She has previously asked for and been granted loans from WAGES which she has fully repaid. She is requesting a third to obtain supplies and better meet the needs of her customers. With this loan she will be able to buy 3 bolts of GTP pagne, 6 bolts of Wax pagne, 3 pieces of lace fabric, and more.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy printed fabric

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
N. Mariam is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala East region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Mariam has a business of running a beauty salon, which she has had for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Mariam is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more braids.  Mariam plans to use the loan in order to expand her business, and generate profit in order to help her family.  In the future, Mariam hopes to own a house.




Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more braids for hair.

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en: Florentina C. is a married woman who lives in Phase 3, Block 5, Fatima Village, Brgy. Rizal, San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a sari sari (general store) and as a wholesaler of Pepsi products. Her husband, Escolastico C. Sr., 55 years old, works as a businessman to earn his living. She has four children who are 20 to 26 years old. Florentina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Florentina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 15,000 PHP; thus, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing 23,000 PHP which she intends to use for her sari sari store so that she can continue to save up for the future and improve their lives. Florentina C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad lives in Bint Jbeil, Lebanon, where the majority of people work in tourism, tobacco farming, and agriculture. Eight months ago, Mohamad opened a restaurant called “Jabal El Sheikh”, which is located in the Villages Public Arena. He can be found in his restaurant 7 days a week, from 7 in the morning until late in the evening, or until the food runs out. 

In addition to sandwiches, Mohamad attracts people to his restaurant through “Arguileh”, a type of hookah or waterpipe, which is a single or multi-stemmed (often glass-based) instrument for smoking tobacco in which the smoke is cooled and filtered by passing through water. Originally from India, hookah has gained popularity around the world.

This is Mohamad’s second time requesting a loan from Al Majmoua and he has demonstrated responsibility and kindness. A constant flow of customers visit his restaurant and business picks up at breakfast time, lunchtime and dinnertime. With the loan Mohamad hopes to receive, he will buy extra tables and chairs in addition to primary material for “Ramadan” the Holy month, since work becomes very active at this time. At the moment, his restaurant is well equipped with the basic necessities. He would like to use the money from this loan in a positive progressive way.

loans.use: Tol buy extra tables and chairs.

loans.name: Lovisa

texts.en:
N. Lovisa is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala East region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Lovisa has a business selling fish, which she has had for 5 years.    

To help expand her business, Lovisa is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more fish.  Lovisa plans to use the loan in order to expand her business and generate profit in order to change her style of living.  In the future, Lovisa hopes to own a big hotel.



Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more fish

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 38-year-old married man living in Lebanon with his wife and 5 children. Ali has been working as a butcher since 1990 and has 25 years of experience. This is Ali’s first time to request a loan from Al Majmoua. He wants to buy two machines for mincing meat according to customers’ needs. Ali is well-known among his neighbors and in his town as an upstanding man who works hard for his family and to grow his business. Ali hopes to expand his work in the future and insure a stable and safe livelihood for his family.

loans.use: In order to buy two machines for mincing meat

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Nakiranda Florence is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in Kampala’s eastern region of Uganda. She is single and has two children. Her children are currently in school. Florence has a business selling vegetables, which she has had for less than one year. She has a pay phone business as well.

To help expand her business, Florence is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. She plans to use the loan to buy more vegetables and so expand her business. She will use all profits to help her children. In the future, Florence hopes to own a house.

About BRAC Uganda

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.

These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age, improve their prospects for the future and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Kulgaaky

texts.en:
Kulgaaky B. lives in Kok-Tokoy village in the north of Kyrgyzstan. She is 46 years old and has two children. Kulgaaky’s son and daughter help her with the farming and the household. She graduated from Kyrgyz National University and works as a teacher of the English language in a local school. She is a very responsible, honest and optimistic person. Unfortunately, the salaries of teachers in rural areas are very low and do not cover the expenses of the household. That’s why, in 1998, Kulgaaky used her savings of 10,000 Kyrgyz soms to start up her business in cattle-breeding and farming. She bought one milk cow, whose milk she sold to her loyal customers. Also, she bought mineral fertilizers to cultivate a plot of land where she planted kidney bean seeds. Kulgaaky and her family worked hard to get a rich harvest. 

Kulgaaky’s striving to provide her children with a better life motivated her to get a loan of 50,000 Kyrgyz soms for cattle breeding. Kulgaaky used her loan as intended and repaid it without any delays. Using the revenues from her first loan, Kulgaaky bought a car for her family. Kulgaaky plans to use this loan of 20,000 Kyrgyz soms to buy one more milk cow in order to increase her milk sales and acquire new customers. Also, she plans to purchase mineral fertilizers to cultivate her plot of land. With the revenues from this loan, Kulgaaky plans to pay for a good education for her son, who wants to be a designer. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Kiva borrowers benefit from a 5% discount on the interest rate if they pay back without delay. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To buy a milk cow and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
Bilal is a 31-year-old married man with one kid. He has been working as a pickup driver since 2005. Bilal’s pickup is his only source of income. He works with some contractors, transporting building materials from one place to another at an exact time and place. He is well known amongst his neighbors and villagers for his good reputation and honesty. Bilal also transports furniture and fills many other requests. He believes that he must work as hard as he can in order to secure a good living for his small family. 

This is Bilal’s seventh loan with Al Majmoua. Bilal makes a good example. Bilal is requesting a loan to do necessary maintenance on his pickup so he can be ready for any job. He’s also going to buy tiles to sell and to fix the floor of his house. His dream is to own a big cement factory and he hopes to achieve it.

loans.use: To do necessary maintenance on his pickup

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en: Juvy P. is a widow who lives in Prk. Kaisdaan, Brgy. Daga, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store and a food-vending business. She has seven children who are between the ages of 6 and 23 years old. One of her children helps her run the businesses. Juvy joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Juvy has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 6,000 PHP, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing 18,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional working capital for her general store and food vending businesses. She wants to continue to save up for the future of her business and family. Juvy P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: N. Joy is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala East region of Uganda. She is single and has two children. All of her children are currently in school. Joy has a business selling secondhand clothes, which she has had for three years. To help expand her business, Joy is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes. Joy plans to use the loan in order to expand her business and generate profit in order to help her children. In the future, Joy hopes to be a big businesswoman. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product on Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future. They target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans and giving Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites C. is a 43-year-old, married woman who supports her family by operating a Ready-to-Wear clothes business. She and her family live in Prk kaisdaan, Brgy Daga, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her Ready to Wear business, she is gradually making her family more stable economically. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 2,000. Marites is now borrowing PHP 10,000 to increase the working capital for her Ready to Wear business. This will be her 6th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Marites aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to provide additional working capital

loans.name: Ziad

texts.en: Ziad is a 33 year-old-married man who has three children. Ziad has been selling and providing maintenance services for all kinds of sanitary ware since 1998. Ziad’s work is not located in one place as he moves from one area to another on request. His clients are very pleased with his products and his way of working. This is his second time requesting a loan from Al Majmoua to buy necessary tools for his business such as an air compressor and other sanitary fixing tools. Ziad hopes to open a shop to sell scrap, sanitary ware & plumbing tools.

loans.use: To buy tools for his business

loans.name: Gumercinda

texts.en:
Gumercinda I. is a married woman who lives in Ibabao, Mactan, Lapu-lapu City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  shell handicrafts and an Avon dealership. Her husband, Celestino I. who is 52 years old, works as a woodcarver. They have 5 children who are 13 to 24 years old. 

Gumercinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 2 cycle loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gumercinda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped increase her monthly profit to PHP 20,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 3rd cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to purchase more materials for her shell handicraft business. She can then continue to save for the future, expand her business and become an exporter of shell handicrafts. Gumercinda I. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase materials

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
N. Betty is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala east region of Uganda.  She is single and has 1 child who goes to school.  Betty has a business selling food in a small hotel. She has been doing this for 6 years.         

To help expand her business, Betty is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more hotel materials like cups and oil. Betty plans to use the loan to expand her business and generate a profit to help her child.  In the future, Betty hopes to own a house.




Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy materials

loans.name: Maristela

texts.en:
Maristela O. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Tapon, Dalaguete, Cebu. She earns a living by operating a beauty salon. Her husband, Eduardo O. who is 42 years old, works as a barber and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 5 children who are 10 to 19 years old. 

Maristela  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 8 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Maristela  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 45,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 75,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 9th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 49,500 which she intends to use as additional working capital and to purchase equipment for her beauty salon. She can then continue to save up for the future and security of her children. Maristela O. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to provide additional capital and to purchase materials

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan B. is a 35-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a furniture business. She lives in Brgy. Tapon, Dalaguete, Cebu. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her furniture  business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 20,000. Susan is now borrowing PHP 28,000 to provide additional working capital for her furniture business. This will be her 11th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 27,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Susan aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. In the photo Susan is with her husband.

loans.use: to provide additional working capital

loans.name: Barbra

texts.en:
Barbra B. is 32 years old and lives in the town of Mattuga in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has 1 child who is in school.  Barbra has operated a business selling cosmetics for 5 years.  

To help expand her business, Barbra is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stock to sell. Barbra hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to make her business bigger. In the future, Barbra hopes to sell more products and educate her child.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetic stock to sell

loans.name: Apolonia

texts.en:
Apolonia A. is a married woman who lives in San Antonio, Brgy. Kabac, Bantayan, Cebu City. She earns a living by operating 3 business ventures: selling Ready to Wear clothes, farming and pig fattening. Her husband, Sulpicio A. who is 53 years old, works as a farmer and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 8 children who are 15 to 32 years old. 

Apolonia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Apolonia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her to earn a monthly profit of PHP 40,000,  raising her family's standard of living.  This time, for her 13th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use as additional working capital. She can then continue to save up for the future, improve her business and pay her children's tuition fees. Apolonia A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to provide additional working capital

loans.name: Essie

texts.fr: G. essie est une femme mariée et mère de 2 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d'adidogomé. en 2008, elle s'est lancée dans le commerce de charbon de bois, le charbons de bois est très utilisé au togo pour faire la cuisine. la demande actuelle de sa clientèle est élevé elle voudrait les satisfaire convenablement elle sollicite alors un crédit pour acheter 20 sacs de charbons de bois. elle s'approvisionne à l'intérieur du pays dans la ville de tsévié.
texts.en:
G. Essie is a married woman and the mother of two children. She lives with her family in the Adidogomé district. In 2008, she started selling charcoal, which is commonly used for cooking in Togo. Her customers' demand is growing, and she would like to satisfy it properly. Therefore she is seeking a loan to purchase 20 bags of charcoal. She stocks up in the interior part of the country, in the town of Tsévie.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing bags of charcoal

loans.name: Jenet

texts.en:
Jenet N. is 49 years old and lives in the town of Mattuga in the Luwero region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children who are in school.  Jenet has been running her restaurant for 6 years.  

To help expand her business, Jenet is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more goods for the restaurant. Jenet hopes that the loan will help her by allowing her to expand her operations and support her family. In the future, Jenet hopes to open up additional branches of her restaurant.

loans.use: to buy more goods for the restaurant

loans.name: Mt Mongai Group

texts.en:
Meet M. Ramadhan M. and the Mt. Rongai Group!  M. is 55 years old, married and has a 20-year-old daughter who goes to school. Additionally, he supports the 7-year-old son of his brother-in-law, and that child also goes to school.  He has been running a business selling dishware for 3 years now and works from 7am to 7pm daily. He is able to make around $67.

This will be M.'s 2nd motisha loan from  Tujijenge Tanzania.  A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. M. used his previous loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase his inventory, and he has repaid that loan successfully. With this loan, M. wants to start selling dishware wholesale.

In the picture M. R, M. is second from the right, second row in a dark shirt.

loans.use: to start selling dishware wholesale.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Felipe Junior

texts.es: Felipe tiene 22 años de edad el es soltero vive en la casa de su madre juntamente con sus hermanos, casa de material de adobe de un piso ubicado en el distrito de la Tinguiña. Felipe es un joven que se dedica  como estivador de guano en la ciudad de pisco , el realiza sus actividades en esa ciudad el viaja diariamente por las mañanas y retorna a su casa por las noches. Felipe es un joven con muchos sueños, el tambien se dedica a la crianza de animales, uno de sus objetivos es poder tener capital para invertir en la inverna de ganado, con el dinero que solicita invertira en alimentos para sus animales.
texts.en:
Felipe is 22 years old and single. He lives in his mother's house together with his brothers. It is a one-story adobe house located in the Tinguiña district. Felipe is a young man who works as a guano loader in the city of Pisco. He travels to the city every morning to do this work and returns to his home at night. Felipe is a young man with many dreams. He also works raising animals. One of his goals is to have enough capital to invest in fattening up his livestock. With the funds he is requesting, he will invest in feed for his animals.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fattening up his livestock

loans.name: Luz Gladis

texts.es: La Sra. Luz tinene 58 años de edad es conviviente tiene 3 hijos 2 mayores de edad y uno de 12 años el cual esta  en el colegio estatal. Ellos viven en casa propia de material de abobe, su conyugue se dedica como obrero de campo. La Sra. Luz se dedica a la crianza y venta de cerdos, viene realizando esta actividad mas de 5 años. La Sra. Luz tiene muchos sueños uno de ellos es poder crecer en su negocio , con el dinero que solicita invertira en capital de trabajo.
texts.en:
Luz is 58 years old. She has a live-in partner and 3 children. Two of her children are adults, and one is 12 years old and goes to a state school. They live in their own house made of adobe. Her partner works as a rural laborer. Luz dedicates herself to raising and selling pigs; she has done this work for more than 5 years. Luz has many dreams, and one of them is to expand her business. She will invest the funds she is requesting to provide working capital for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Kokou Amen

texts.fr: A. kokou amen, est un jeune célibataire âgé de 26 ans, il habite à zanguéra qui est un quartier au nord ouest de la ville de Lomé. il a commencé en 2007 le commerce de matériaux de construction. il fait ce commerce dans sa propre boutique qu'il a appelé" ETS SPERO". il s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. son stock de marchandise est en baisse raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de 5 tuyaux PVC,  26 tuyau orange, 46 robinet, 20 paquets de ciment, 36 fers et divers. c'est avec le revenu de son activité qu'il subvient à ses propres besoins.
texts.en:
Atifou Kokou Amen is a young single man, 26 years old. He lives in Zanguéra, a district in the Northeast of the city of Lomé. In 2007 he launched a business selling construction supplies. He keeps his own shop named “ETS SPERO.” He stocks up at the big market of Lomé. His stock is being depleted, which is why he is seeking a loan from WAGES in order to purchase five PVC pipes, 26 orange pipes [for propane gas], 46 faucets, 20 packs of cement, 36 soldering irons and other miscellaneous items. It is thanks to the revenue from this business that he is able to support himself.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing construction supplies

loans.name: Liliana Patricia
